4: Online Etymology Dictionary obeisance n. late 14c., "act or fact of obeying," from Old French  obeissance  "obedience, service, feudal duty" (13c.), from  obeissant , present participle of  obeir  "obey," from Latin  oboedire  (see  obey ). Sense in English altered late 14c. to "bending or prostration of the body as a gesture of submission or respect" by confusion with  abaisance . Related:  Obeisant .
